awd_titl_txt: PFI:AIR - TT:  Low cost method for harvesting algal biomass from dilute cultures
awd_abstract_narration:
This PFI: AIR Technology Translation project focuses on improving and demonstrating the recovery of algal biomass from dilute growth cultures with minimal cost and energy input. This project has the potential to lead to economical use of alternative fuels derived from algal biomass. The lack of low-cost technologies for harvesting algae is currently a major bottleneck in the commercial production of fuels from microalgae. When cultivated in open raceway ponds, microalgae concentrations are very low - typically 0.1%. Stimuli-sensitive hydrogels are capable of selectively soaking up large quantities of culture media (without absorbing microalgae cells), thus efficiently increasing concentrations of the microalgal cultures, leading to a more efficient recovery of the microalgal cells. This allows separation of solid cells from liquid media in a cost- and energy-efficient manner and without use of additional chemicals as compared to competing chemical flocculation methods. In addition, the absorbed liquid in the hydrogel can subsequently be released easily through small increases in hydrogel temperature (from ambient to 35°C). The recovered (de-swelled) hydrogels, as well as the growth medium, can then be reused over multiple cycles to create a sustainable algae harvesting process through effective recycling of water and un-utilized water-soluble nutrients.

This project addresses the following technology gaps as it translates from research discovery toward commercial application: (i) continuous hydrogel harvesting in a scalable prototype that minimizes exposure of the gel to mechanical attrition and preserves gel longevity; (ii) use of waste flue gases to de-swell hydrogels through heat integration, (iii) establishes benchmarks for harvesting efficiency, highest culture concentrations achievable, quality of harvested product, and hydrogel stability during prolonged-use.  In addition, undergraduate and graduate students involved in this project will receive innovation and technology translation experiences through design, development and testing of hydrogel-based algae harvesting prototypes.

por.por_cntn:
Currently, a major hurdle for commercial-scale production of fuels from algae is recovering algal biomass from growth media with minimal cost and energy input.  When cultivated in open raceway ponds, microalgae concentrations are very low – typically 0.1% (w/w). For fuel production, the challenge is to harvest these dilute cultures efficiently and economically. Also, commercial-scale harvesting methods should also allow for recycling of water and unutilized water-soluble nutrients – critical for environmental sustainability of algae production.

In this project we have developed prototypes for a novel low-energy technology for harvesting algae though use of stimuli-sensitive hydrogels. Hydrogels are superabsorbent cross-linked polymers that can “soak-up” large quantities of water/media when immersed in algal cultures and filter out algae cells that are unable to penetrate the small gel pores. This preferential uptake of the aqueous phase results in an increase in biomass concentration in the culture. After absorbing growth media, the swollen hydrogels can be recovered and de-swelled by applying a stimulus – for example, temperature-sensitive gels de-swell when subjected to a small increase in temperature (up to 35 °C). The de-swelled hydrogels can then be re-used to absorb more medium. Thus, a cyclic process can be implemented that allows repeated use of gel and gel use over multiple cycles to keep concentrating the cultures.

During the development and demonstration of the algae harvesting prototype in this project, we have addressed several knowledge gaps to expedite eventual commercial deployment of this technology. These outcomes are described below.

We have improved hydrogel swelling and deswelling performance through synthesis of novel hydrogels that have semi-interpenetrating networks. These networks act as channels in the gel structure to rapidly uptake water. We have also synthesized macroscopic (3-5 mm) spherical shaped gels that allow water to freely flow around the gels to such that all available surfaces are utilized, and the harvesting process is efficient.

We have addressed challenges to maintaining hydrogel mechanical stability and longevity during use and continuous operation in an industrial process. Our harvesting system design minimizes gel rupture through mechanical abrasion and the hydrogels we have synthesized show relatively high mechanical strength and elasticity. As a result, no hydrogel loss due to attrition was observed during our demonstrations.

Through rigorous mass and energy balances during prototype testing, we have assessed hydrogel harvesting process efficiencies and determined appropriate “operating windows” for the process. We have optimized ratios of gel to culture volume and developed a staged operating approach. At these operating conditions, we showed that high concentrations of harvested cultures (~100 g/L) can be achieved without significant loss in performance or biomass loss.

The mass and energy balance data collected during prototype operation was used to perform techno economic assessments of the harvesting process. Using estimates of capital and operating costs we were able to determine that the algae harvesting costs by our approach are significantly lower than other state-of-the art methods.

We also developed system designs for integrating the algae harvesting process with low value (waste) heat streams such as flue gases and low-cost solar thermal systems like solar ponds.  In these system designs, the carbon and energy footprint of the hydrogel harvesting approach was determined to be much lower than what would be feasible with other harvesting approaches.

The technology developed during this project has broad impacts outside of the algae industry. During this project we were able to interact with representatives from other industries such as food and wastewater treatment. From these conversations it was apparent that the impact of our work could easily extend to other solid-liquid separations including recovery of sludge during municipal wastewater treatment and recovery of dilute pulps and minerals.

Finally, our project trained students at multiple levels and from groups typically underrepresented in Engineering. The project supported a female-Hispanic graduate student, one female undergraduate student, and one male Hispanic undergraduate student.
